captions.text: Right I'm going to do a lovely dish that I'm really, really excited about. It's the kind of food that I love
to cook when I'm at home. It is the most delicious tomato salad with chorizo. I don't want to
slice it perfectly, sort of odds and sods
and put the
chorizo in a little bit of olive oil.
Now what's gonna happen in this pan is

it's going to start rendering out all that
natural fat and flavour. We want to get
this crispy and we're going to turn that into like a warm dressing
for these tomatoes.
I mean for a perfect
tomato salad
just cut it up

not in perfect. I don't like it when it's
slices or wedges. Just do it all
different.

A little bit of shallott or scallion, just
helps to create a little bit of a
hum.
And then just a nice pinch
of black pepper,
a good pinch of sea salt.
And then some good olive oil.
Absolutely
one of the hero ingredients of Spain.

And another ingredient, sherry vinegar,
right it's absolutely brilliant, it's

from this region. You can get in all the
supermarkets back home now. When you taste it
as a vinegar

It's not just acid, it's kind of got flavour, a
tiny bit of sweetness in there

Go and get some an it will transform your
dressings.
And then herb wise, i mean parsley's a big deal out here. So you take some of that, you know,
I've picked some beautiful little globe basil, or tiny basil from the flower pots where I'm
staying.
Beautiful.

And then I want you to roll it up, almost like
a little cigar. And just
slice it up.
And then just sprinkle it like that.

In five minutes, the flavor of those
tomatoes because of the beautiful things you
put on it, will be ridiculous.
Finely slice this bit of garlic.
Angle that little baby
and put in the garlic. Yeah! Look at that,
And at this point, right
you want to watch the garlic like a hawk.

As it just starts taking on colour, a few
tablespoons of the vinegar
will stop that frying process

It will sort of smell intense for a minute but it will cook
the vinegar away

and then you're left with that sweetness
and flavour.

And that's when i got over to my tomato
salad
and just check this out.
Look at that!
The lovely, crispy chorizo.

Then put some of that lovely fat in
there as well.
And with this, look at it.
You've got the red and the dark. Look how dark this chorizo's gone right, it looks
almost burnt. Delish!
One of the best things in the world, you've got to go do that.

title: The best Tomato Salad and Chorizo by Jamie Oliver

comments.text: really too much oil for me﻿
comments.author: 李少华

comments.text:
As a Spanish, i just can say that looks disgusting!.
Tomato salad with virgin uncooked olive oil? perfect.
Casting the chorizo oil into the salad just ruins it.

In my opinion, You should have dried the excess oil of the chorizo, toss 
the chorizo into the salad and then maybe it would be fine ﻿

comments.author: Michael Nees

comments.text:
very delicious and very harmful to your body, the olive oil raised to such 
temperature is a source of tremendous amounts of free oxigen species - 
never use liquid oils for frying/cooking, the only fats that are good for 
frying are the solid ones like grease or cocconut oil, butter also isnt a 
too good idea but still better than the liquid ones.﻿

comments.text: best?   how dare you...﻿

comments.text: Mmmmmmm... Chorizo﻿
comments.author: pottybhoy

comments.text:
i just bought some chorizo from my local market but mine looks nothing like 
the chorizo jamie had around 0:16 his looks like a dark blood red while 
mine looks like a chile red o.0 and his looks a bit hard mine feels pretty 
soft like a normal raw sausage.... is there something wrong with the 
chorizo i buy? ﻿
comments.author: john king

comments.text:
Im form Spain, And all I can tell you, is to recognize a good chorizo for 
the Smell and of course taste. typically, it has a strong pimenton 
(paprika) smell, a little bit garlicy.
I use to prepare Macaronni with Chorizo, and what I use for it is one of 
the brand "la hoguera" spicy!
comments.author: ikky kano

comments.text:
+john king  You need to buy cured chorizo sausage, I think (90% sure) that 
you are buying fresh chorizo sausage that needs to be cooked. In the video, 
jamie uses cured chorizo sausage (sausage that has been smoked/cooked and 
then has been refridgerated). I'm from Australia, so I don't know where in 
america you could find it... best to check the cured meats section where 
the salami is your best bet. Hope this helps
comments.author: darky23

comments.text:
+ShutTheFuckUpDonkey ya i specifically asked for spanish chorizo o.0

but i went to grocery type of stores i'll try going to a legit butcher i 
suppose!

one more thing, for that spanish chorizo jamie had was it already cooked? 
because it looked pretty hard and easy to cut if not ready to eat at that 
point, or should it be hard already when bought o.0

Thanks!
comments.author: john king

comments.text:
+john king Try looking for or asking for 'Spanish Chorizo' its the one 
thats eaten in Europe. America seems to mix in some South American sausages 
and calls them Chroizo too but the one Jamie is using is the Spanish 
variety. 

Maybe try going to some delis or spanish stores and asking or looking there?
comments.author: M8 U say 1 more fokin thing n ill bash ur head in

comments.text:
+ShutTheFuckUpDonkey do you know where you can find them? i'm in cali, 
beverly hills o.0 i've been to a ton of stores nothing looks legit o.0
comments.author: john king

comments.text:
Yes, you didn't buy real chorizo you got a 'chorizo' sausage. In America it 
seems like a lot of people are trying to jump on the bandwagon and are just 
creating spicy sausages and calling them 'chorizo'.
